importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report marks the most recent update on the flooding crisis, indicating ongoing impact and governmental response.
The date corresponds to the day when the death toll was officially reported at 64 and missing persons were updated to 65, signaling a critical update in disaster response.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred over a period of time last week, emphasizing the duration and severity of the disaster.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded on Wednesday, which was the peak of the disaster, triggering major flooding and landslides.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
A total of 65 people are still missing, with the majority in Hidalgo (43), Veracruz (18), and Puebla (4).
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military troops, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist with emergency relief, including food and clean water distribution.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply to the affected regions, where about 263,000 users lost power.
Approximately 100,000 homes have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such extreme rainfall, raising questions about early warning systems.
Governors and national authorities are coordinating efforts to manage response across the affected states.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has experienced severe flooding across five states due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food and water, while nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to affected regions. About 100,000 homes have been damaged, with some near rivers effectively destroyed.
